# Cyber Scams in Singapore (2019–2025): Trends, Preparedness, and Recommendations

## Introduction  
Singapore has witnessed a sharp surge in cyber and online scams in the post-pandemic period. From e-commerce swindles to sophisticated banking phishing schemes, scammers have exploited digital adoption and human vulnerabilities. This report examines recent scam trends, evaluates the state of cybersecurity awareness among Singaporeans, and assesses whether current education and outreach efforts are sufficient. We focus on vulnerable groups – especially seniors and the less digitally savvy – and identify gaps in preparedness. Finally, we propose comprehensive, forward-looking solutions for consideration by relevant government ministries and agencies.

## Rising Trends of Cyber Scams (2019–2025)  
**Explosion in Cases and Losses:** Online scams have proliferated dramatically in Singapore over the past five years. The number of reported scam cases nearly **quintupled** from about **9,500 in 2019** to **46,600 in 2023**, according to the Ministry of Home Affairs【11†L142-L150】. In 2024, scam reports hit a new high of **51,501 cases**, a **10.6%** rise from 2023【8†L339-L347】【8†L349-L357】. The financial toll has grown even more stark: victims lost **S$651.8 million in 2023**, and in **2024 losses soared to about S$1.1 billion** – the first time annual scam proceeds crossed the billion-dollar mark【8†L349-L357】. This represents a **70% jump in losses** in one year【8†L349-L357】. Cumulatively, scammers have stolen well over **S$3 billion from Singapore victims since 2019**, underscoring an escalating criminal industry【10†L5-L12】.

**Common Scam Types:** The nature of scams has evolved in sophistication and scale. In 2024, the **most frequently reported scams** were e-commerce purchase scams (over **11,600 cases**, ~22.7% of all cases), followed by job recruitment scams, phishing scams (often involving bank OTPs), investment scams, and “fake friend” impersonation calls【2†L141-L149】. **E-commerce scams** – e.g. bogus online sales of products like concert tickets – formed the largest share by volume【7†L1579-L1587】【7†L1619-L1627】. However, the scams causing the **greatest financial damage** were different: **investment frauds** (including cryptocurrency schemes) caused the highest losses, accounting for roughly **28% of money lost in 2024**, followed by scams involving **government official impersonation**, **job scams**, **malware-enabled scams**, and **business email compromise (BEC)**【2†L143-L148】【2†L145-L153】. These syndicates often convince victims to transfer large sums – for instance, one single malware-related crypto scam in 2024 cost a victim **S$125 million**【7†L1642-L1650】. Overall, scams now contribute a significant share of Singapore’s crime; as early as 2019 they comprised over a quarter of all crimes, and that share has only grown【10†L33-L37】.

**Post-Pandemic Drivers:** Several factors have fueled this “scam pandemic.” COVID-19 accelerated the shift of commerce, banking, and social interaction online, giving scammers a larger attack surface. More people shopping or working from home meant more targets for e-commerce scams and job scams. Criminal groups adapted quickly: for example, **phishing scams tripled and investment scams jumped 77% from 2020 to 2021** in Singapore, with many **socially isolated seniors** falling prey【23†L59-L67】. Scammers also capitalized on pandemic anxieties and digital unfamiliarity – impersonating banks, government agencies, or employers in convincing ruses. The result is a **sustained onslaught of fraud** that continues to evolve in tactics.

**Notable Incidents:** High-profile cases have spotlighted vulnerabilities. A pivotal example was the late-2021 **OCBC Bank SMS phishing scam**, in which **790 customers were duped** by fake bank messages and lost **S$13.7 million** within weeks【38†L114-L122】. This incident – unprecedented in scale for a local bank – exposed gaps in both customer vigilance and bank response. (OCBC acknowledged its customer service fell short during the incident and provided full goodwill reimbursements to victims【38†L126-L133】.) The episode spurred industry-wide security upgrades in early 2022, such as removal of clickable links in bank communications and implementation of “kill-switch” emergency account locks, to prevent similar exploits【11†L148-L156】. More recently, 2024 saw scammers leverage **cryptocurrency and malware**; one victim’s extreme **S$125 million loss** in a crypto scam was enabled by malicious code planted during a fake job interview【7†L1642-L1650】. These cases illustrate how scammers continuously refine their methods – from simple e-mail phishing to complex social engineering and tech-enabled heists.

## Impact and Victim Profile  
**Financial and Social Costs:** The monetary losses from scams are staggering – over **S$1.1 billion in a single year (2024)** – but the impact is also deeply personal. Thousands of Singaporeans have seen life savings, retirement funds or hard-earned salaries drained by fraudsters. The police noted that while a majority of scam cases involve relatively small sums (over 70% of cases in 2024 involved losses under $5,000), a few **high-value cases (3.3% of cases) accounted for over 70% of total losses**【1†L80-L87】【1†L82-L90】. This includes not just wealthy investors but also ordinary individuals coerced into emptying multiple accounts or taking loans. Beyond dollars, victims often suffer emotional trauma, shame, and loss of trust in digital services. The wider society also bears costs – from law enforcement resources to the erosion of confidence in e-commerce and e-banking.

**Who Are the Victims:** A common perception is that only the elderly or less-educated fall for scams. **In reality, victims span all demographics**【30†L59-L67】. **Young adults** are heavily targeted – for example, *one survey found that nearly 1 in 3 Singaporeans had been scammed, and among those aged 18–34 the victimization rate was almost 50%*【33†L77-L85】. These “digital natives” engage frequently in online shopping, social media, and investing apps, making them **prime targets** despite their tech-savvy reputation【33†L77-L85】. Many younger victims are lured by get-rich-quick investment schemes or fake job offers on social platforms. **Working professionals** in their 30s–40s have also been ensnared by scams like China official impersonations or business email compromises. In short, tech literacy alone has not immunized the population – in fact, over **84% of Singaporeans *believe*** they can spot a scam, yet tests showed only **40% could identify a phishing email correctly**【33†L83-L91】. This overconfidence gap leaves even educated groups vulnerable.

That said, **seniors and less digitally literate individuals remain at higher risk of severe consequences.** While those **aged 65+ comprised only ~8% of scam victims in 2024, they lost the most per victim on average**【5†L173-L178】. Elderly victims tend to be less familiar with digital authentication or scam red flags, and may be more trusting of callers claiming to be officials. Many seniors also have substantial savings or retirement funds that, once lost, are difficult to recover. Community organizations observe that seniors who are **socially isolated and less educated in digital matters are prime targets**, as scammers prey on their loneliness or lack of awareness【23†L59-L67】. There have been local cases of elderly individuals nearly transferring **seven-figure sums** to fraudsters, thwarted only by last-minute intervention of bank or police personnel【21†L25-L33】【21†L35-L43】. Clearly, *both* the old and the young require stronger protections – the former due to limited digital know-how, the latter perhaps due to complacency and high exposure.

## Cybersecurity Preparedness of Singaporeans  

### Public Awareness and Education  
**General Awareness:** Public awareness of cyber scams has certainly increased in recent years, thanks to frequent media reports and government advisories. Surveys indicate most Singaporeans *know* of common scams; for instance, terms like “phishing”, “OTP scam” or “love scam” are regularly in the news. However, awareness does not always translate into effective caution. A 2025 study revealed that **two-thirds of people would not know how to respond if targeted by a scam**, despite ostensibly high awareness【33†L67-L75】. Many Singaporeans still fall back on ad-hoc advice from family or friends when dealing with suspicious situations, rather than official guidance【33†L71-L74】. Such peer advice may be well-intentioned but can sometimes be inaccurate, leading to delayed action. This indicates a gap in *practical preparedness* – people may recognize the idea of scams, but lack concrete steps to verify and respond (e.g. how to check if a call is legitimate, how to report or where to seek help).

**Education System (Youths):** Singapore’s education system has begun incorporating cyber safety and scam awareness topics, but coverage can be expanded. Currently, **schools integrate anti-scam lessons across various subjects**. For example, in **Character and Citizenship Education (CCE)** classes, students learn to evaluate the credibility of online information and are taught how to recognize phishing, e-commerce scams, love scams and the like【32†L120-L128】. In **lower secondary Food and Consumer Education**, students are taught consumer rights, financial responsibility and not to be misled by scams when shopping online【32†L124-L131】. Even **Social Studies** touches on cybersecurity risks and media literacy, training students to question sources both online and offline【32†L127-L133】. Beyond formal curriculum, schools sometimes host talks by the police or cybersecurity agencies, and the Singapore Police Force (SPF) and Inter-Ministry Committee on Scams (IMCS) have partnered with schools and Institutes of Higher Learning to spread anti-scam messages【32†L133-L138】. These efforts mean that the current generation of students is more exposed to cyber-safety knowledge than earlier generations. **However**, given the fast-evolving scam landscape (e.g. scams now involving AI deepfakes or cryptocurrency), educational content needs continual refresh. There is room to include more *hands-on simulations* (such as mock scam exercises or interactive games) to let students experience and practice responding to scam scenarios. Notably, a study found **teenagers tend to be overconfident** – 98% of teens surveyed believed they could detect scams, a confidence that is likely misplaced without real-world experience【33†L83-L91】. Strengthening school programmes with updated content (like how to spot AI-generated fake videos or voice scams) and reinforcing that *anyone* can be fooled would further improve youth preparedness.

**Adult Digital Literacy:** For the adult population – especially those who finished schooling before cyber education was common – public education is critical. Many working adults have learned about scams informally or after a bad experience. The government has mounted public awareness campaigns (discussed in the next section) and banks splash warnings on their apps, yet the continued rise in victims suggests gaps in outreach. A concerning trend is that **victims often ignore warnings** even when they are present. Authorities reported cases where individuals, in the throes of a scammer’s manipulation, *refused to believe they were being scammed* – even when warned by bank staff or police officers【7†L1658-L1666】【11†L159-L167】. Scammers adeptly exploit human trust and fear, sometimes convincing victims that legitimate warnings are false. This highlights that education can’t be just a one-way flow of information; it must also address psychological aspects (why people fall prey) and repeatedly reinforce key “safe behaviors” until they become second nature. Overall, while general awareness is high on paper, **true readiness** – knowing how to *act* when confronted with a scam attempt – remains insufficient for a large segment of the public.

### Protection for Seniors and Vulnerable Groups  
**Outreach to Seniors:** Given that elderly citizens are particularly vulnerable, there have been dedicated initiatives to educate and protect them. The Cyber Security Agency (CSA), in partnership with IMDA and SPF, launched the **SG Cyber Safe Seniors Programme in 2021** to raise cybersecurity awareness among seniors【39†L52-L60】. Under this programme, government-employed **Digital Ambassadors** (through IMDA’s Digital for Life movement) conduct training at community centers and libraries, teaching seniors basic cyber hygiene and how to spot scams【39†L56-L64】. Importantly, materials are provided in all four official languages and in easy-to-understand formats【23†L59-L67】. CSA and its partners developed a **handbook for seniors**, run regular quizzes and interactive workshops in the heartlands, and even involve student volunteers to provide **one-on-one assistance** during these sessions【39†L58-L65】. This peer and inter-generational support approach has helped reach many elderly residents in a personal way. According to public reports, IMDA’s digital literacy programmes (like Seniors Go Digital) have engaged over **130,000 seniors since 2020** through small-group coaching and pop-up booths at community events (teaching skills from using smartphone apps to recognizing scam calls). Such numbers are encouraging, yet there are over 600,000 residents above age 65 in Singapore – indicating more ground to cover.

**Challenges with Seniors:** Despite these efforts, some seniors still struggle to apply safe practices. Common issues include difficulty handling security features (e.g. using banking tokens or 2-Factor Authentication devices), low trust in digital platforms (leading some to call back scammers out of fear of “official” trouble), and simply being less exposed to technology. Scammers have cruelly exploited elderly persons by impersonating police or government officers on the phone, knowing seniors tend to be deferential to authority. The SPF highlights that **impersonation scams by “government officials” often ensnare older victims and lead to very high losses**, as these victims are persuaded to transfer large sums under the guise of assisting an investigation【11†L159-L167】. Another challenge is that a segment of seniors, even after attending workshops, might have memory issues or cognitive decline that makes it hard to retain lessons – they may require repeated reminders or caregiver support to stay vigilant. Community organizations like Lions Befrienders have started **“Say No to Scams” programmes** where volunteers regularly remind isolated seniors about ongoing scam tactics【27†L0-L4】. Banks, too, are recognising the need to cater to seniors: for instance, some banks now allow customers to *opt in* for higher protection modes (such as lower default transfer limits or branch-only transaction approvals for those uncomfortable with online banking). The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has even urged banks to **consider the needs of seniors in authentication processes**, so that anti-scam measures remain effective without excluding those with low digital literacy【21†L21-L29】. In summary, significant outreach is underway for seniors, but it must continue expanding in depth and breadth. The elderly population is diverse – from those in their 60s who may still be active online, to those in their 80s or 90s who may barely use smartphones – so a one-size approach is not enough. Tailored strategies and persistent community support are required to truly safeguard our seniors.

**Less Educated or Non-Tech Users:** Beyond age, individuals with lower education or limited English proficiency also face higher scam risk. Many scam advisories are in English by default; efforts have been made to provide translations (the National Crime Prevention Council produces multilingual scam alert posters, and CSA’s seniors handbook covers Malay, Chinese, Tamil), but ensuring comprehension is an ongoing task. Domestic workers or migrant workers are another vulnerable group – there have been cases of scammers posing as embassy or immigration officials to scare foreign workers into paying “fines”. Government outreach has begun to include messages in migrant workers’ dormitories and via NGOs to cover these groups. Additionally, people who are new to the internet (for example, some middle-aged individuals who only went online during COVID-19 for essential tasks) might not be fluent in identifying fake websites or scam pop-ups. For them, basic digital literacy programs (like how to install antivirus, how to use messaging apps safely) are as important as advanced cyber warnings. Singapore’s **“Digital for Life”** national movement explicitly aims to include all segments in the digital journey; aligning scam education with this movement will help reach those who might otherwise be left behind. 

### Role of Financial Institutions and Industry  
**Banks and Customer Education:** Banks, being on the front line of many scams (particularly internet banking fraud), have ramped up customer security measures in recent years. After a spate of banking-related scams, MAS and the Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) introduced a package of safeguards in 2022 to bolster digital banking security. These included **setting default transfer limits ($5,000)**, requiring additional confirmations for high-risk transactions, providing a one-click **“kill switch”** for customers to freeze their account if fraud is suspected, and **co-locating bank staff inside the Police Anti-Scam Centre** to expedite fund recovery【40†L123-L132】【40†L128-L136】. Banks also agreed to remove SMS/email hyperlinks and implement delays for activating new payees – all to reduce phishing success. Crucially, an **ABS Standing Committee on Fraud** was established to coordinate industry anti-scam efforts. This committee formalised five key workstreams: **customer education, authentication, fraud surveillance, customer handling & recovery, and equitable loss sharing**【40†L159-L167】. The inclusion of *customer education* as a top workstream is notable – it signals that banks must actively educate their users, not just rely on technology. Indeed, banks have since been sending more frequent scam alert messages via email/app, publishing scam advisories on websites, and training frontline staff to advise customers. For example, OCBC Bank started running workshops for elderly customers, even inviting scam victims to share their experiences as cautionary lessons【21†L9-L17】. RHB Bank similarly hosted community fraud awareness talks at a Residents’ Network, teaching dozens of seniors how to spot fake calls and texts【23†L73-L81】. Such outreach by financial institutions is a positive development, though it is not yet uniform across the sector. Smaller financial firms (remittance companies, insurers, investment brokers) are also beginning to push out client education on fraud, given scams like fake investment platforms have affected their consumers.

**Responsibility and Reimbursement:** A critical aspect of preparedness is how losses are handled when prevention fails. Historically, scam victims could rarely get compensation from service providers (banks or telcos), because the victim was often deemed to have authorized the transfer (albeit under deception). However, the sheer scale of losses and public outcry (after cases like the OCBC scam) prompted a re-examination of this approach. Regulators recognized that expecting individual consumers to bear all the losses was neither fair nor sustainable for trust in the digital economy. In early 2023, MAS and the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) proposed a **Shared Responsibility Framework (SRF)** for phishing scams【18†L19-L24】【18†L25-L32】. Under this forthcoming framework, liabilities for scam losses may be *shared* between customers and financial institutions if certain duties of care are not met. In essence, banks will be **held to specific duties** (e.g. implementing effective fraud detection, customer warnings, prompt response) and customers likewise have duties (e.g. protecting their credentials, not clicking dubious links). If a bank falls short (say, its systems failed to block a clearly fraudulent transfer or it did not provide appropriate safeguards), it may be required to compensate the victim for part of the loss【5†L173-L181】. Conversely, if a customer blatantly ignored all provided warnings, the compensation might be limited. The details are being finalized, but **the direction is clear** – there is now regulatory expectation on banks to actively prevent scams and to support customers who are defrauded, rather than a “you’re on your own” stance. This shift is driving banks to invest even more in anti-scam tech and education, as ultimately **prevention is preferable to reimbursement**. 

**Technology and Platform Providers:** Preparedness also involves the tech platforms through which scams often occur – for example, telcos, social media, and e-commerce sites. The government has engaged telecommunications companies to help combat scams: Singapore telcos are now required to **implement SMS sender ID registries and spam filters** to block messages spoofing as banks or government entities. There is also a push to label overseas incoming calls (a “[+]-prefix” is added on phones) to warn users that a call claiming to be local is actually from abroad. These measures have had some effect, though scammers continually seek workarounds (like using messaging apps instead of SMS, or buying local SIM cards illicitly – an issue the government is addressing via stricter SIM card registration laws【9†L409-L417】【9†L413-L421】). Social media and online marketplaces are another vector – scams proliferate on Facebook, Instagram, Telegram, Carousell, etc. The authorities (e.g. IMDA under the new Online Criminal Harms Act) now have powers to compel platforms to take down scam content or block fake accounts more swiftly. For instance, under the law passed in 2023, the government can direct internet services to **block phishing websites or domains** and instruct social media platforms to remove posts that promote scams or impersonate government bodies. These tools have been used to tackle malicious sites and fraudulent crypto investment ads targeting Singapore users. While tech companies’ cooperation is improving, it’s an ongoing battle to keep online ecosystems safe. Public education messages increasingly emphasize that **“Government officials will NEVER ask for personal details or transfers over a call”**【39†L21-L27】 and that **banks will never send clickable login links via SMS** – simple rules that, if internalized, would stop a large share of scams at the outset.

## Government Education and Outreach Efforts  

### Public Awareness Campaigns  
The Singapore government, recognizing the severity of the scam scourge, has mounted extensive public education campaigns in recent years. The **Cyber Security Agency (CSA)** leads annual national cybersecurity awareness campaigns. In **2021**, CSA launched the **“Better Cyber Safe than Sorry”** campaign to instill four basic cyber hygiene tips in the public’s mindset【16†L57-L66】【16†L68-L72】. These tips were: *use strong passwords and enable 2FA* on accounts, *spot the signs of phishing*, *install antivirus software*, and *promptly update software*【16†L67-L72】. The campaign drew parallels between cybersecurity habits and everyday safety (e.g. comparing software updates to locking doors), and was advertised widely on TV, public transport, and online platforms【16†L57-L65】. By **2023**, CSA rolled out its fifth campaign titled **“The Unseen Enemy”**, highlighting that cyber threats and scams are often invisible yet pervasive in daily life【15†L51-L59】. This campaign reinforced *four key cyber tips* in fighting scams: **Enable 2FA & use strong passphrases**, **Beware of phishing scams (think before you click)**, **Keep software updated**, and **Add protective tools like ScamShield and antivirus apps**【15†L63-L71】. Eye-catching visuals and slogans were deployed on buses, MRT stations, digital billboards, and social media feeds【15†L57-L65】【15†L63-L71】. CSA also collaborated with popular banks, e-commerce platforms and local influencers to amplify these messages to their audiences【15†L73-L79】. This multi-channel outreach is crucial in repeatedly exposing the public to safe online practices. There is evidence that such campaigns have improved general awareness of things like 2FA and phishing – for instance, many more people now know not to click strange links, even if not everyone adheres perfectly.

In addition to CSA’s efforts, the **National Crime Prevention Council (NCPC)** (a government-supported volunteer council) runs complementary anti-scam publicity. In 2023, NCPC launched a national anti-scam slogan **“I can ACT against scams”** to urge the public to take concrete steps, summarized as **A.C.T: Add, Check, Tell**【30†L63-L70】. **“Add”** means install the **ScamShield** app (which blocks known scam calls/SMS) and add antivirus protection【30†L67-L75】; **“Check”** means always verify requests for money or data through official sources (e.g. call the bank’s hotline if someone claims to be from your bank)【30†L79-L88】【30†L91-L99】; and **“Tell”** means inform your family and friends about scams and report incidents promptly【30†L99-L107】【30†L109-L117】. The ACT campaign has been promoted via short films, radio ads, social media posts, and even community roadshows. Notably, authorities set up a **24/7 Scam helpline (tel: 1799)** that anyone can call if unsure about a call or message – this is publicized as a resource to “Stop and Check” suspicious situations【39†L21-L27】. NCPC also produces bite-sized scam alert graphics that are shared on WhatsApp and community notice boards, often in multiple languages, to reach heartlanders who may not follow official websites. 

These campaigns have had encouraging results in specific areas. For example, SPF reported **significant declines in certain scam types in 2024 due to public education and enforcement** – *fake friend call scams* (where scammers impersonate friends asking for money urgently) saw both case numbers and amounts drop substantially after publicity and cross-border police action【7†L1629-L1637】. Similarly, *social media impersonation scams* and *tech support malware scams* declined in frequency, which SPF attributed in part to measures implemented by government, banks, and telcos to warn users and block avenues【7†L1637-L1644】. While overall scam figures are still high, these examples show that targeted education combined with action can suppress specific threats. A challenge, however, is that as soon as one modus operandi becomes well-known, scammers pivot to new stories. Thus, public education must be *continuously adaptive* – recent efforts have started addressing emerging threats like cryptocurrency fraud and AI-driven scams (for instance, CSA’s latest materials include scenarios on deepfake videos and fake investment platforms). 

### Law Enforcement and Legislative Measures  
The government has progressively strengthened laws and operational capabilities to combat scams, which indirectly boosts public confidence in dealing with online transactions. A notable initiative is the SPF’s **Anti-Scam Command (ASCom)**, established in March 2022, which centralizes police resources to respond to scams in real-time【7†L1662-L1670】. ASCom works closely with banks and telecommunication companies to freeze illicit fund flows and takedown phishing infrastructure. In 2024 alone, the police **recovered over S$182 million** of scammed monies through prompt intervention, and even *averted* an estimated **S$483 million in potential losses** by interceding when victims were in the middle of a scam transaction【7†L1662-L1670】【7†L1664-L1671】. Such interventions often involve analyzing banking transaction patterns to spot likely scam payments and contacting the account holders or temporarily halting transfers. In one dramatic case, an **82-year-old man was stopped from losing $3.7 million** after police and bank staff identified unusual activity and intervened three separate times when scammers tried to persuade him to transfer funds【21†L25-L33】【21†L31-L35】. These efforts demonstrate a whole-of-system vigilance that complements individual vigilance.

On the legal front, Singapore has introduced new legislation specifically targeting scam tactics and facilitators. In 2023, Parliament passed the **Online Criminal Harms Act**, which, as mentioned, grants authorities quicker powers to block or remove online content facilitating scams (phishing sites, scam web ads, etc.). In 2025, another innovative law – the **Protection from Scams Act** – came into effect, empowering police to issue **“Restriction Orders”** to banks to *temporarily freeze* a suspected victim’s bank account if the person is in the midst of being scammed【11†L135-L143】【11†L168-L176】. This law was designed to protect those stubborn few who, even after being warned, insist on transferring money to scammers. From 2019 to 2023, scam cases involving **voluntary victim transfers (“self-effected” scams) remained exceedingly high – 86% of cases in early 2024**【11†L154-L162】. The Police had no legal means to stop a determined victim from sending money away, until now. Under the new Act, if the Police assess that an individual is likely about to be scammed (for example, a retiree under the sway of a fake “China police” caller trying to clear out her account), they can direct the bank to restrict that person’s outgoing transfers for a short period【11†L170-L178】【11†L189-L197】. This is a drastic measure to be used as a last resort, but it could save individuals from irreparable financial harm. Appropriate checks are built in – the order can be lifted if the situation is clarified – but it signals how far Singapore is willing to go to thwart scams. Additionally, penalties for being a **money mule** (people who allow their bank accounts to be used to launder scam money) have been stiffened. Under amendments to laws like the Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act and Computer Misuse Act, those who sell their bank account or Singpass login to scammers can face jail and be forced to forfeit gains【9†L399-L407】【9†L401-L409】. In 2024, police arrested over **8,000 scammers and money mules** in island-wide operations, and more than 660 were prosecuted – including 110 charged under these strengthened laws that target enablers of scams【9†L409-L417】. By choking the local facilitators and swiftly freezing fraudulent proceeds, the government aims to make Singapore a hard target for scam syndicates.

Overall, the government’s multifaceted response – **education, engineering, enforcement** – has ramped up significantly. The creation of an Inter-Ministry Committee on Scams means agencies ranging from Home Affairs, Communications and Information, Education, Finance, and Social and Family Development are coordinating on this issue. Public outreach and improved defenses are starting to show results in stabilizing the growth of scam cases (for instance, the number of cases grew ~11% in 2024, slower than previous years, even as total losses jumped due to a few big cases【5†L163-L171】). Yet, the consensus is that the fight is far from over, and in some respects will only get tougher as scams mutate.

## Gaps and Challenges in the Current System  
Despite all the measures in place, several gaps persist in Singapore’s cyber scam defenses. These shortfalls need to be addressed to achieve a truly scam-resilient nation:

- **Residual Lack of Awareness/Alertness:** A portion of the public remains inadequately informed or insufficiently skeptical. This is evident from the steady stream of victims falling for fairly *known* scams (e.g. e-commerce bargains that are too good to be true, or callers asking for OTPs). While outreach has improved awareness *in general*, it may not be penetrating deeply into certain communities or translating into day-to-day caution. For example, **foreign language speakers and less educated individuals** might not fully grasp campaigns delivered mainly in English, creating pockets of lower awareness. Additionally, new entrants to the digital world (such as some seniors or young teens getting their first smartphone) may not receive timely education before encountering scams. Thus, pockets of the population still have low baseline knowledge of cyber risks.

- **Human Factor and Social Engineering:** The **human element** remains the weakest link. As noted, over 80% of scams involve *social engineering* – scammers manipulating victims to willingly transfer money【11†L154-L162】. No amount of firewalls or spam filters can fully prevent a person from being tricked if they trust the wrong person. Singaporeans may have a cultural tendency to be trusting or deferential to authority, which scammers exploit. The current education efforts, while telling people “don’t trust unsolicited calls”, sometimes collide with deeply ingrained habits of trust. Moreover, scam tactics exploiting *emotions* – fear (in impersonation scams), greed (in investment scams), or love (in romance scams) – can override rational judgment. This means our education and intervention methods might not sufficiently account for psychological manipulation. Some victims continue to transfer funds **even after multiple warnings**, essentially under a form of social coercion【11†L159-L167】. The system lacks a robust way to “deprogram” someone in the grips of a scam narrative beyond the new drastic measure of freezing accounts. In summary, the challenge is less about pure *knowledge* and more about *behavioral change* – getting people to internalize skepticism and break the spell of scam narratives.

- **Elderly and At-Risk Groups Not Fully Reached:** While programs for seniors exist, it’s unclear if we are reaching the *majority* of at-risk elders or just a fraction. Many seniors who live alone or are not socially active may not attend community workshops. Some might also overestimate their ability to handle scams – for instance, an IMDA survey found only **44% of seniors were at least moderately confident in spotting scams**, meaning over half admitted low confidence, yet others might be falsely confident【27†L37-L42】. The current outreach might not adequately cover those with mobility issues or those who do not actively seek help. Similarly, migrant workers and low-income individuals might not be attending existing programmes due to work schedules or lack of awareness. These gaps leave a segment of the population as “low-hanging fruit” for scammers.

- **Emerging Threats Outpacing Response:** Scammers continuously innovate, and there can be a lag before countermeasures catch up. For example, the surge of **malware-enabled scams via fake apps** in 2023 took some time to be widely recognized; by the time advisories went out, significant losses had occurred (one case accounted for a huge crypto theft)【7†L1642-L1650】. The rise of **AI-generated scams** (such as deepfake voices of loved ones crying for help, or convincingly tailored phishing messages) is a looming threat that the general public is not yet well-prepared for. Only **5% of Singaporeans feel confident in detecting AI-driven fraud**【33†L95-L100】, which is worrisome as we expect such scams to increase. The government has begun talking about these issues, but proactive public guidance (e.g. “if you get an urgent call supposedly from your child but asking for money, be aware it could be AI fake”) is still nascent. In short, our scam awareness campaigns may sometimes be reactive (after the scam becomes widespread) rather than proactive. The **speed of threat identification** and public advisory could be improved.

- **Coordination and Information Sharing:** With multiple agencies and private sector stakeholders involved, coordination is crucial. While the Inter-Ministry Committee and ABS Fraud Committee exist, there may be room for more seamless information sharing. For instance, scammer techniques spotted by banks might need to be rapidly communicated to telecommunication firms and social media companies to block vectors, and vice versa. A fully integrated “early warning system” for scams is still in development. Victims sometimes report feeling passed around between the bank, police, etc. when trying to seek help. Smoother processes (perhaps a one-stop support channel for scam victims beyond just the helpline) could be established. Also, while Singapore collaborates with regional law enforcement (e.g. with Malaysia to bust call centers【7†L1631-L1639】), cross-border cooperation can always be expanded given many syndicates operate from overseas.

- **Bank and Corporate Practices:** Some gaps lie in implementation by institutions. Not all banks have the same level of rigor in anti-scam user experience – for example, some banking apps now force users to read scam advisories when performing certain actions, but others may not. There have been calls for banks to introduce *dynamic warnings* (e.g. if an elderly customer suddenly tries to transfer an unusually large sum, prompt a “Are you sure this isn’t a scam?” confirmation or require a bank officer to call). It’s unclear if all banks have deployed such targeted interventions. Additionally, outside of banking, other industries like e-commerce platforms or gig economy apps may not be doing enough to warn or educate users. A person renting a flat online or buying on a marketplace might not see any fraud warning until after they’ve been cheated. Hence, a gap exists in **industry-wide adoption of anti-scam best practices** beyond the financial sector. 

- **Public Fatigue and Complacency:** Finally, as scam warnings have become ubiquitous, there is a risk of **alert fatigue** – people may start tuning out repetitive warnings. Some may feel “scams are so common, if it happens it happens” or develop a false sense that they personally won’t be duped (overconfidence). This complacency is dangerous. The gap here is in finding fresh, engaging ways to convey warnings so that the public doesn’t become desensitized. Empathy-led education (as some experts suggest) that really makes individuals *feel* the impact of scams (perhaps by hearing victims’ stories) might be necessary to break through complacency. 

In summary, Singapore’s anti-scam framework is robust and improving, but needs to address the human and emerging-tech angles more deeply. Education must become more action-oriented and pervasive, and systems must be nimble to adapt to new scam tricks. With these gaps identified, we now move to concrete recommendations to strengthen our national resilience against scams.

## Recommendations for Strengthening Singapore’s Cyber-Scam Defenses  
Addressing the complex scam problem requires a **comprehensive, multi-pronged strategy**. Below are recommended actions targeted at key stakeholders and ministries, aiming to fill the gaps identified. These solutions build upon existing efforts and introduce new measures to better protect Singaporeans of all ages:

1. **Enhance Public Education through Empathy and Real-Life Simulation**  
   *Lead agencies: Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI) – including CSA and IMDA; Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA); Ministry of Education (MOE)*  
   Traditional awareness campaigns should evolve into more engaging, empathy-led education. **We recommend incorporating real scam simulations and personal stories into public outreach.** For example, CSA and SPF could set up interactive exhibits or online modules where people can safely experience a mock phishing attempt or an AI-generated scam call, then learn from it. This hands-on approach can expose overconfident individuals to the fact that scams can fool them, correcting the inflated self-assurance many have【33†L83-L91】. It also aligns with expert suggestions to use *real-world learning* and case studies to improve scam readiness【33†L135-L144】. In parallel, leverage victim testimonials (with consent) in media – hearing a fellow citizen describe “I never thought I’d be duped, but I was” can be powerful. The goal is to foster an emotional understanding of scams’ impact, not just intellectual awareness. MCI’s campaigns might partner with local broadcasters to create short drama vignettes or documentaries on scam victims and heroes (similar to the Crimewatch TV episodes, but focused on scams). By evoking empathy, we make the public more receptive to anti-scam advice and less prone to blame victims. 

   Furthermore, **public education must be continuous and in multiple languages/formats.** Translate key campaign materials into Mandarin, Malay, Tamil and dialects, using simple analogies relevant to those communities. Grassroots channels like community centres, clan associations, and religious organizations should be enlisted to spread anti-scam messages in culturally appropriate ways. For instance, scam talks could be integrated into activities at seniors’ clubs or during festive community dinners (when attendance is high). We also recommend exploring partnerships with popular media (radio DJs, TV personalities, internet influencers) to periodically remind followers about new scam tactics. Just as health campaigns constantly remind people about dengue or COVID-19, scam awareness needs to be a persistent drumbeat – without causing fear, but encouraging vigilance.

2. **Strengthen Cybersecurity Curriculum and Training in Schools and Workplaces**  
   *Lead agency: MOE (with support from MCI/CSA and MOM)*  
   The foundation for long-term cyber resilience is education from young. MOE should further fortify the curriculum on cybersecurity and digital financial literacy. **We propose making cyber scam awareness a formal component of national education across all levels – with age-appropriate depth.** For primary schools, this might mean simple “Stranger Danger” analogies for the online world (don’t trust unknown messages, always ask an adult). At secondary level and junior college, incorporate modules on common scam case studies, how to verify authenticity online, and the psychology of scams. As noted in MOE’s parliamentary response, elements exist in CCE and other subjects【32†L120-L128】; we recommend expanding these with up-to-date examples each year. Students could be tasked to do projects (e.g. designing an anti-scam poster or app) or given scenario-based assessments (e.g. analyzing a mock scam message) to ensure practical understanding. **Cyber safety should also be part of Polytechnic and University orientation programs**, since tertiary students begin to handle finances (loans, investments) independently and are actively targeted by certain scams (job scams, loan scams). An annual workshop or e-learning module could be mandated for first-year tertiary students, possibly in collaboration with CSA’s youth outreach (like the SG Cyber Safe Students Programme).

   Beyond schools, working adults need continuous training as well. The Government could encourage or incentivize **workplace cybersecurity awareness trainings**. Many companies already conduct periodic phishing email tests and IT security briefings for employees – this practice should be promoted across all sectors, not just in IT firms. For example, the Monetary Authority (MAS) can require financial institutions to include scam awareness refreshers for their staff and front-line customer service, so they in turn can educate customers. The Ministry of Manpower could work with unions and employer associations to roll out a standard “fraud awareness” module in existing training frameworks (perhaps as part of SkillsFuture courses or HR onboarding). A national e-learning portal could be offered where any adult can log in and take an interactive course on identifying scams, with multimedia content drawn from real cases. Such an initiative might be led by CSA/IMDA under the *Digital for Life* umbrella, ensuring it’s accessible to all citizens (including those outside formal education).

3. **Expand and Deepen Outreach to Seniors and Other Vulnerable Groups**  
   *Lead agencies: MCI/IMDA (Digital Inclusion), Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF), People’s Association (PA)*  
   While current programmes for seniors are commendable【39†L52-L60】, we need to further expand their reach and tailor them to the varying needs of older adults. **First**, increase the number of *Digital Ambassadors* and community workshops such that they cover more neighbourhoods and senior living facilities. Consider a target to reach *every HDB estate’s senior community* at least once a year with an anti-scam workshop or info-session. Partner with PA and town councils to piggyback on existing senior activities (e.g. monthly mahjong clubs or exercise groups can start with a 10-minute scam tip segment). **Second**, create a *“Scam Guardian” volunteer program* where tech-savvy seniors (perhaps retirees who were bankers, teachers, etc.) are trained to be ambassadors to their peers. Peers may trust advice from someone of their own generation more. The police have piloted “P.R.A.I.S.E.” senior volunteer schemes for crime prevention【21†L39-L43】; this can be expanded specifically for scam education.

   **Third**, employ more targeted safeguards for seniors in the banking system. We suggest that MAS work with banks on an *opt-in security setting* for vulnerable customers: for example, a senior can register to have any transaction above a certain amount delayed until a bank officer contacts them for verification. Alternatively, a family member could be designated to receive an alert when large transfers occur (with the senior’s consent and in compliance with privacy laws). This acts as a circuit-breaker in case the senior is being coached by a scammer in real time – a pattern we’ve seen in several cases. We also recommend that banks simplify their user interfaces for seniors: perhaps a dedicated “senior mode” in banking apps with larger text and very clear, repetitive warning prompts (e.g. “Have you confirmed this request is real? If someone on the phone asked you to do this, it is likely a SCAM.”). MAS could issue guidelines on user interface considerations for elderly or less educated users, ensuring inclusivity in fintech.

   **Fourth**, for other vulnerable segments like migrant workers and domestic helpers, deliver scam education in their native languages and through channels they trust. This might involve roadshows in dormitories, pocket-sized brochures in Bengali, Chinese, Tamil, etc., and engaging major employers to brief their workers. As many migrant workers may be targeted by overseas scammers (pretending to be from their home country authorities), MFA and embassies can also help disseminate warnings. In summary, a *community-centric approach* is needed – meeting vulnerable groups where they are, rather than expecting them to find the information themselves.

4. **Bolster Technological and Legal Defenses Proactively**  
   *Lead agencies: MHA/SPF, MCI/IMDA, GovTech, MAS*  
   The government should continue to strengthen the tech and legal infrastructure that shields citizens, anticipating new scam tactics. **On the technology front**, we recommend investing in advanced scam detection and blocking tools. GovTech’s development of tools like **ScamShield and the Scam Analytics Tactical Intervention System (SATIS)** – which uses data analytics to identify scam websites and communications – is a great example【33†L99-L107】. These efforts should be accelerated and expanded: for instance, deploying AI to monitor and **flag scam trends on social media** (in partnership with platform providers) and to detect mass spam calls or messages in real-time for prompt blocking. The **ScamShield mobile app** (which filters scam SMS and calls) should be aggressively promoted – every smartphone user in Singapore ought to have it installed as a first line of defense. To achieve this, the government could collaborate with telcos to push automatic prompts or even include ScamShield in phone setup for local users. In addition, explore integrating ScamShield’s filtering intelligence at the network level, so even those without the app get some protection (e.g. a network-wide SMS filter for known scam keywords or blacklisted numbers).

   **Legally**, Singapore must stay nimble. If scammers shift to new platforms or methods, laws/regulations might need updates. For example, if cryptocurrency scams continue rising, MAS may consider tighter regulation of crypto advertisements or requiring local internet service providers to block access to known fraudulent crypto sites (with a nimble whitelist/blacklist process). The new **Restriction Orders** power should be used judiciously but decisively – SPF should develop clear protocols on when to invoke it, and officers must be trained to identify those extreme cases where victims are in trance-like compliance with scammers【11†L159-L167】【11†L168-L176】. Additionally, enhance cross-border legal cooperation: build on successes with Malaysian police in syndicate busts【7†L1631-L1639】 by forging deeper ties with regional countries where scams originate (China, Philippines, Indonesia, etc.). MHA could initiate regional dialogues specifically on scam crime, aiming for faster intelligence sharing and joint operations. The recently established ASEAN Cybersecurity Cooperation strategy could include scam mitigation as a priority item.

   Another recommendation is to **hold enablers accountable**. This includes not just money mules (which is being done with tougher laws and prosecutions) but also potentially companies that negligently allow scams to propagate. For instance, if a social media platform consistently fails to remove scam ads that victimize users, the government should not shy away from sanctions or public rebuke to spur better self-regulation. The *Shared Responsibility Framework* should extend beyond banks to encompass telcos and online platforms as “key parties in the ecosystem” responsible for anti-scam duties【40†L169-L177】. This multi-party responsibility will incentivize all private stakeholders to actively implement anti-scam measures or face consequences.

5. **Foster a Scam-Resilient Culture and Community Support**  
   *Lead agencies: All ministries via public communications, National Crime Prevention Council, community organizations*  
   Ultimately, defeating scams is not only about government action but also about cultivating a vigilant culture in society. We recommend initiatives to make scam awareness as commonplace as, say, road safety or public health consciousness under the **Total Defence** ethos. One idea is to designate an **annual “Anti-Scam Awareness Day”** or week, where nationwide events (talks, exhibitions, media programs) focus on scams – similar to how Singapore has a National Safety Month or Cybersecurity Awareness Month. This could rally schools, companies, and community groups to run their own anti-scam activities in synchrony, reinforcing messages through multiple channels at once.

   Encourage a norm where people *look out for one another*. For example, neighbourhood committees can set up “digital watch groups” – neighbors volunteer to help less savvy residents verify suspicious messages (much like a Neighborhood Watch but for scams). Families should be urged to have conversations about scams: Parent-teacher associations can provide discussion guides for parents to teach children and vice versa (children warning elderly parents). The SGScamWISE program mentioned in a recent report focuses on community empowerment – training individuals who then educate their circles【33†L147-L155】 – this model should be supported by government grants and recognition. We propose small grants to community clubs or NGOs that come up with creative anti-scam projects (e.g. a youth group developing a mobile game about spotting scams, or an arts group producing comics in vernacular languages on scams). Such ground-up efforts can complement official campaigns and may connect better with certain audiences.

   Additionally, provide **support for scam victims** as part of building resilience. Being scammed can be traumatic; victims might be reluctant to speak up, which then limits others learning from these incidents. The government could partner with counselling services or financial advisory services to help victims recover emotionally and plan their financial next steps, reducing the stigma of being a victim. Visible support will encourage reporting and cooperation with law enforcement. Over time, as more people share their stories and help others avoid the same fate, the community becomes stronger against scammers.

6. **Continuous Review and Foresight**  
   *Lead agency: Inter-Ministry Committee on Scams (IMCS)*  
   Lastly, make sure the fight against scams stays ahead of the curve. The IMCS should set up a dedicated **Scam Foresight and Analytics unit** (possibly within CSA or SPF) that continuously studies emerging scam trends locally and globally. This unit can work with academia and industry to anticipate the next tactics – be it scams via the metaverse, or using AI to generate fake law enforcement IDs, etc. Proactively run “red team” exercises: think like scammers to identify vulnerabilities in new digital services (for example, as Singapore rolls out digital banking or government e-services, consider how they could be abused in scams and patch those gaps or educate users accordingly). Scenario planning exercises can be conducted (similar to crisis simulations) to test national readiness for, say, a widespread deepfake scam incident. The insights from this foresight group should be fed into policy updates and public advisories promptly. In essence, institutionalize *agility* in our approach – scammers pivot quickly, so must we.

By implementing the above recommendations, Singapore can significantly tighten the screws on scam operations and enhance the public’s ability to avoid deception. Each recommendation addresses specific gaps – from human behavioral weaknesses to systemic coordination – and together they form a robust strategy to safeguard our increasingly digital way of life.

## Conclusion  
Cyber scams will likely persist as a long-term threat, evolving with technology and social trends. However, Singapore can turn the tide by making scam awareness and preparedness a national priority on par with physical security. The post-2019 spike in scams was a wake-up call; the response so far has been strong but must continue to intensify. By educating our citizens comprehensively, protecting the vulnerable, deploying smart technologies, and enacting agile policies, we can drastically reduce the success rate of scammers. This report has identified the critical areas for improvement and offered actionable solutions for the Government and stakeholders. Implementing these recommendations will require coordination across ministries – from MHA and MCI to MOE, MAS, MSF and beyond – reflecting the fact that tackling scams is truly a **whole-of-nation effort**.

Singapore has often been lauded for its safety and trustworthiness in the physical realm; the aim now is to extend that reputation to the digital sphere. With decisive action, Singapore can become a place where cyber criminals find little quarter – a well-informed public, backed by vigilant institutions, will mean most scams are spotted and foiled before any damage is done. We owe this to our citizens, especially the most vulnerable, to ensure that our smart nation is also a safe nation. The fight against scams is unending, but by staying united, vigilant, and proactive, we will safeguard Singapore’s digital future from those who seek to exploit it【33†L156-L159】. 

**Sources:** The findings and data in this report draw from official Singapore Police Force scam statistics, government press releases, parliamentary records, and reputable news outlets and research studies, including but not limited to CSA and SPF publications【8†L349-L357】【11†L142-L150】【33†L77-L85】, media reports from *The Straits Times*, *Channel NewsAsia*, *Reuters*【5†L159-L167】【7†L1611-L1619】, and expert analyses on public scam readiness【33†L83-L91】【33†L95-L100】. These references have been cited throughout the report to provide evidence and context for the issues discussed. The recommendations are informed by best practices and gaps identified in the aforementioned sources.

Legislative agility is essential: regular review and update of regulations must anticipate new vectors (e.g., crypto, deepfakes), and enforcement of the Shared Responsibility Framework should be broadened to include platform providers and telcos. Cross-border collaboration on enforcement and intelligence must be deepened, especially with regional partners.

Accountability for enablers—such as money mules, negligent platforms, and facilitators—should be clearly delineated, with consequences for inaction or complicity.

## 5. **Foster a Scam-Resilient Culture and Community Support**

A truly resilient society requires more than top-down regulation; community and family engagement are key. An annual national Anti-Scam Awareness Day should be instituted, rallying schools, employers, and civic groups for synchronized education and engagement events.

Neighbourhood digital watch groups and family-oriented discussion guides will empower Singaporeans to look out for one another, especially the vulnerable. Grant support for innovative, ground-up anti-scam projects (youth games, vernacular comics, creative campaigns) will foster local ownership of the problem.

Support systems for scam victims—counselling, financial advice, peer support—must be scaled up to reduce stigma, promote reporting, and facilitate learning from incidents.

## 6. **Continuous Review and Strategic Foresight**

A dedicated foresight and analytics unit within the Inter-Ministry Committee on Scams should be established to anticipate emerging threats, commission red-teaming exercises, and ensure rapid updating of public advisories and institutional protocols. Collaboration with academia and industry on threat intelligence, behavioral research, and scenario planning will ensure Singapore remains ahead of the evolving threat landscape.
